Dreams have fascinated philosophers for thousands of years, but only recently have dreams been subjected to empirical research and scientific study. Chances are that you've often found yourself puzzling over the content of a dream, or perhaps you've' wondered why you dream at all. First, let's start by answering a basic question: What is a dream? A dream can include any of the images, thoughts and emotions that are experienced during sleep. Dreams. can be extraordinarily vivid or very vague; filled with joyful emotions or frightening images, focused and understandable or unclear and confusing.
Why do we dream? What purpose do dreams serve? While many theories have been proposed no consensus has emerged. Considering the time. we spend in a dreaming state, the fact that researchers do not yet understand the purpose of dreams may seem baffling. However, it is important to consider that science is still unraveling the exact purpose and function of sleep itself: Some researchers suggest that dreams serve no real purpose, while others believe that dreaming is essential to mental, emotional and physical well-being.
Next, let's learn more about some of the most prominent dream theories. Consistent with the psychoanalytic perspective, Sigmund Freud's theory of dreams suggests that dreams are a representation of subconscious desires, thoughts and motivations. According to Freud, people are driven by aggressive and sexual instincts that are repressed from conscious awareness. While these thoughts are not consciously expressed, they find their way into our awareness via dreams. In his famous book The Interpretation of Dreams (1899). Freud wrote that dreams are "..... disguised fulfilments of repressed wishes."

questions.uddipok: Write the graph below shows "Population Growth Rate" from 2009 to 2013. Describe the graph in 150 words. You should highlight and summarize the information given in the graph.

sub_questions.explanation:
Population growth rate of Bangladesh from 2009 to 2013
The graph provides information about the population growth rate of Bangladesh from 2009 to 2013 .
In 2009, the rate was 2.73 % 2.73 \% 2.73% , then in 2010 the rate decreased to 2.22 % 2.22 \% 2.22% . In 2011 , the rate came down to 1.95 % 1.95 \% 1.95% . Then the increase occurred in 2012 and the rate was 2.20 % 2.20 \% 2.20% . Again, in 2013 the population rate decreased and came down to 1.35 % 1.35 \% 1.35% . The graph indicates that the highest rate was population growth rate in 2009 was alarming while the rate in 2013 was encouraging.
From the graph, it is clear that population growth rate decreased rapidly and remarkably over time and within a span of 5 years the population decreased more than a half, i.e. from 2.73 in 2009 to 1.35 in 2013. This is really an encouraging feature of population growth in the context of Bangladesh. I think this has been made possible because of some effective measures taken by the govt. to control the growth of population, like the family planning programme of having no more than 2 children.

questions.uddipok:
The following is the beginning of a story. Complete it in your own words.
Long ago, a young man found life in the family in his village full of problems and sufferings. Quarrels, ill-feelings, jealousy, enmity, all were part of everyday life there........

sub_questions.explanation:
Title: The Village of Peace
Long ago, a young man found life in the family in his village full of problems and sufferings. Quarrels, ill-feelings, jealousy, enmity — all were part of everyday life there. No one seemed happy, and even small matters turned into big fights. Tired of the toxic atmosphere, the young man decided to leave.
He walked for days and finally reached a quiet, distant village nestled in the hills. The people there were kind, honest, and lived in harmony. There were no loud arguments, no envy in their hearts. The young man felt peace for the first time. He decided to settle there.
Years passed, and he built a small home and started a family. But slowly, he noticed signs of tension among his neighbors—disagreements, misunderstandings, even jealousy. He was confused. “How did this happen?” he wondered. He reflected deeply and realized the truth: peace doesn’t come just from escaping problems—it must grow within.
So he changed himself. He practiced patience, spoke kindly, forgave easily, and helped others. Slowly, his behavior began to influence others. People started trusting one another again. Smiles returned to faces. The peace he once searched for outside had now been built from within.
Moral: Peace isn’t a place you find—it’s something you create.

questions.uddipok: Suppose, you are Mahin. Your friend Abir is very afraid of English. Now, write a letter to him describing how to be competent in English.

sub_questions.explanation:
Dear Abir,
I hope this letter finds you well. I understand that you're feeling apprehensive about English, but I'm here to assure you that with a bit of effort and the right approach, you can become competent in English.
Firstly, it's essential to change your mindset about learning English. Instead of seeing it as a daunting task, try to view it as a fun and exciting journey. Remember, everyone starts somewhere, and making mistakes is a natural part of the learning process.
To improve your English skills, here are some practical steps you can take:
1. Start Small : Begin by learning basic vocabulary and common phrases. You can use flashcards, language learning apps, or online resources to help you memorize words.
2. Practice Regularly : Consistency is key. Try to dedicate a little time each day to practice reading, writing, listening, and speaking in English. You can read English books or articles, listen to podcasts or songs, and even engage in conversations with English speakers if possible.
3. Set Realistic Goals : Set achievable goals for yourself, such as learning a certain number of new words each week or improving your pronunciation. Celebrate your progress along the way to stay motivated.
4. Immerse Yourself : Surround yourself with English as much as possible. Watch English movies or TV shows, listen to English radio stations, and try to think in English. Immersion can significantly accelerate your learning process.
5. Don't Be Afraid to Make Mistakes : Remember that making mistakes is part of learning any new language. Don't let fear hold you back from practicing or speaking English. Embrace your errors as opportunities to improve.
6. Seek Feedback : If you have the opportunity, ask for feedback from English speakers or teachers. Constructive criticism can help you identify areas for improvement and refine your skills.
7. Stay Motivated : Find reasons to stay motivated, whether it's to advance your career, communicate with people from different cultures, or simply challenge yourself. Remind yourself of your goals and the benefits of learning English.
Abir, I believe in you. Learning English may seem daunting at first, but with perseverance and dedication, you'll undoubtedly become more competent in the language. Feel free to reach out to me if you need any support or encouragement along the way.
Best wishes,
Mahin
